title: How to Fix Error 0xc0000142 - Application Unable to Start
metaTitle: Fix 0xc0000142 Application Error in Windows 11/10 (2025)
metaDescription: Complete guide to fix the 0xc0000142 application was unable to start correctly error. Works for games, Office, and other apps.
excerpt: The 0xc0000142 error prevents applications from starting correctly. This guide provides tested solutions.
author: System Admin Team

sections.heading: Understanding This Error
sections.content:
The **Error 0** error is a Windows system error that can disrupt your work or gaming session. This guide provides step-by-step solutions to resolve this issue and prevent it from recurring.

This error typically indicates a system-level problem that can range from corrupted files to hardware issues.

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
This error commonly occurs due to:

1. **Missing or Corrupted System Files**: Essential Windows components are damaged
2. **Registry Issues**: Windows Registry entries are corrupted
3. **Software Conflicts**: Third-party applications interfering with system operations
4. **Insufficient Resources**: Low disk space, memory, or CPU resources
5. **Permission Problems**: Insufficient privileges for required operations
6. **Outdated Components**: Windows or application components need updating

sections.heading: Solution 1: Run Windows Troubleshooter
sections.content:
Windows includes built-in troubleshooters that can automatically detect and fix many issues:

**Step 1**: Open Windows Settings (Win + I)

**Step 2**: Navigate to **System** → **Troubleshoot** → **Other troubleshooters**

**Step 3**: Run relevant troubleshooters:
- **Windows Update** - For update-related errors
- **Program Compatibility** - For application errors
- **Hardware and Devices** - For hardware-related issues
- **Power** - For power-related problems

**Step 4**: Follow the on-screen instructions and apply any suggested fixes

**Step 5**: Restart your computer if prompted

sections.heading: Solution 2: System File Repair
sections.content:
Windows has built-in tools to repair corrupted system files:

**Step 1**: Open Command Prompt as Administrator
- Press **Win + X** → select **Terminal (Admin)**
- Or search "cmd" → right-click → **Run as administrator**

**Step 2**: Run System File Checker
```
sfc /scannow
```
Wait for the scan to complete (10-15 minutes).

**Step 3**: If issues found, run DISM repair
```
DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth
```
This may take 15-30 minutes.

**Step 4**: Restart your computer and try again.

sections.heading: Solution 3: Check Hardware and Drivers
sections.content:
Driver and hardware issues can cause application errors:

**Update Device Drivers:**
1. Press **Win + X** → **Device Manager**
2. Expand each category and look for yellow warning icons
3. Right-click problematic devices → **Update driver**
4. Choose **Search automatically for drivers**

**Update Graphics Driver:**
Visit your GPU manufacturer's website:
- NVIDIA: nvidia.com/drivers
- AMD: amd.com/support
- Intel: intel.com/download-center

**Check Disk Health:**
1. Open Command Prompt as Admin
2. Run: `wmic diskdrive get status`
3. All drives should show "OK"

sections.heading: Preventing Future Errors
sections.content:
Keep your system stable with these practices:

**Regular Maintenance:**
- Run Disk Cleanup monthly to remove temporary files
- Use **sfc /scannow** periodically to check system integrity
- Keep at least 15-20% of your drive space free

**Software Practices:**
- Install software from official sources only
- Uninstall programs you don't use
- Avoid installing multiple antivirus programs

**Updates and Backups:**
- Enable automatic Windows updates
- Create System Restore points before major changes
- Back up important files regularly

**Hardware Care:**
- Keep your PC clean and well-ventilated
- Monitor temperatures during intensive tasks
- Consider replacing old hard drives (5+ years)

title: Fix All Elden Ring DLL Errors on PC
metaTitle: Elden Ring DLL Errors Fix - MSVCP, VCRUNTIME, D3D (2025)
metaDescription: Fix Elden Ring DLL missing errors including MSVCP140.dll, VCRUNTIME140.dll, and DirectX errors.
excerpt: Elden Ring requires Visual C++ and DirectX runtimes to run properly.
author: System Admin Team

sections.heading: What Causes This Error?
sections.content:
The **DLL** error blocking your application from starting is a system-level issue that many users encounter. This Dynamic Link Library provides essential functions that the application depends on.



This guide provides multiple verified solutions, ordered by success rate. Most users resolve this issue with the first or second method.

sections.heading: Solution 1: Install Missing Runtime Components
sections.content:
Try installing these common runtime packages:

**Option A - Visual C++ Redistributable**:
- [Download VC++ 2015-2022](https://aka.ms/vs/17/release/vc_redist.x64.exe)

**Option B - DirectX Runtime**:
- [Download DirectX](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=35)

**Option C - .NET Framework**:
- [Download .NET Framework](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-framework)

Install all of these, then restart and try your application again.

sections.heading: Solution 2: Verify Game Files
sections.content:
Corrupted game files can cause DLL errors. Verifying files will download any missing or damaged files.

**For Steam:**
1. Open Steam Library
2. Right-click **your application** → **Properties**
3. Go to **Installed Files** tab
4. Click **Verify integrity of game files**
5. Wait for verification to complete (may take 5-30 minutes)
6. Restart Steam and launch the game

**For Epic Games:**
1. Open Epic Games Library
2. Click the **three dots (⋯)** on your application
3. Select **Manage** → **Verify**
4. Wait for verification

**For GOG Galaxy:**
1. Open GOG Galaxy
2. Select your application
3. Click **Settings icon** → **Manage Installation** → **Verify / Repair**

sections.heading: Solution 3: Run System File Repair
sections.content:
Windows has built-in tools to repair corrupted system files:

**Step 1**: Open Command Prompt as Administrator
- Press **Win + X** → select **Terminal (Admin)**
- Or search "cmd" → right-click → **Run as administrator**

**Step 2**: Run System File Checker
```
sfc /scannow
```
Wait for the scan to complete (10-15 minutes).

**Step 3**: If issues found, run DISM repair
```
DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth
```
This may take 15-30 minutes.

**Step 4**: Restart your computer and try again.

sections.heading: Solution 4: Advanced Troubleshooting
sections.content:
If the above solutions don't work, try these advanced steps:

**1. Clean Boot Windows**
This eliminates software conflicts:
- Press **Win + R** → type **msconfig** → Enter
- Go to **Services** tab → Check **Hide all Microsoft services** → Click **Disable all**
- Go to **Startup** tab → Click **Open Task Manager** → Disable all startup items
- Restart and test your application

**2. Create a New User Account**
Corrupted user profiles can cause DLL errors:
- Settings → Accounts → Family & other users → Add other user
- Create a local account and test your application there

**3. Check for Malware**
Run a full system scan with Windows Defender or your antivirus.

**4. Update Windows**
- Settings → Windows Update → Check for updates
- Install all available updates including optional ones

sections.heading: Prevention Tips
sections.content:
Keep your system healthy with these practices:

1. **Keep Windows Updated**: Enable automatic updates to receive latest fixes

2. **Install All Runtime Packages**: Keep Visual C++, DirectX, and .NET Framework current

3. **Use Official Downloads**: Only download software from official sources

4. **Quality Antivirus**: Use a reputable antivirus that doesn't cause false positives

5. **Regular Maintenance**: Run Disk Cleanup and SFC scan periodically

sections.heading: Understanding This Error
sections.content:
Encountering **System Error** on your Windows PC? This comprehensive guide will help you diagnose and fix the problem. We've compiled solutions based on success rates from thousands of users.

Let's get your system back to normal.

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
This error commonly occurs due to:

1. **Missing or Corrupted System Files**: Essential Windows components are damaged
2. **Registry Issues**: Windows Registry entries are corrupted
3. **Software Conflicts**: Third-party applications interfering with system operations
4. **Insufficient Resources**: Low disk space, memory, or CPU resources
5. **Permission Problems**: Insufficient privileges for required operations
6. **Outdated Components**: Windows or application components need updating

sections.heading: Solution 1: Run Windows Troubleshooter
sections.content:
Windows includes built-in troubleshooters that can automatically detect and fix many issues:

**Step 1**: Open Windows Settings (Win + I)

**Step 2**: Navigate to **System** → **Troubleshoot** → **Other troubleshooters**

**Step 3**: Run relevant troubleshooters:
- **Windows Update** - For update-related errors
- **Program Compatibility** - For application errors
- **Hardware and Devices** - For hardware-related issues
- **Power** - For power-related problems

**Step 4**: Follow the on-screen instructions and apply any suggested fixes

**Step 5**: Restart your computer if prompted

sections.heading: Solution 2: System File Repair
sections.content:
Corrupted Windows system files can cause DLL errors. Use these repair tools:

**Open Administrator Command Prompt:**
Press **Win + S**, type "cmd", right-click **Command Prompt**, select **Run as administrator**

**Run these commands in order:**

1. **Check system file integrity:**
```
sfc /scannow
```

2. **Repair Windows image (if SFC found issues):**
```
DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth
```

3. **Re-run SFC after DISM:**
```
sfc /scannow
```

Restart your computer after these repairs complete.

sections.heading: Solution 3: Check Hardware and Drivers
sections.content:
Driver and hardware issues can cause application errors:

**Update Device Drivers:**
1. Press **Win + X** → **Device Manager**
2. Expand each category and look for yellow warning icons
3. Right-click problematic devices → **Update driver**
4. Choose **Search automatically for drivers**

**Update Graphics Driver:**
Visit your GPU manufacturer's website:
- NVIDIA: nvidia.com/drivers
- AMD: amd.com/support
- Intel: intel.com/download-center

**Check Disk Health:**
1. Open Command Prompt as Admin
2. Run: `wmic diskdrive get status`
3. All drives should show "OK"

sections.heading: Preventing Future Errors
sections.content:
Keep your system stable with these practices:

**Regular Maintenance:**
- Run Disk Cleanup monthly to remove temporary files
- Use **sfc /scannow** periodically to check system integrity
- Keep at least 15-20% of your drive space free

**Software Practices:**
- Install software from official sources only
- Uninstall programs you don't use
- Avoid installing multiple antivirus programs

**Updates and Backups:**
- Enable automatic Windows updates
- Create System Restore points before major changes
- Back up important files regularly

**Hardware Care:**
- Keep your PC clean and well-ventilated
- Monitor temperatures during intensive tasks
- Consider replacing old hard drives (5+ years)

- [Download x86 version](https://aka.ms/vs/17/release/vc_redist.x86.exe)

**Step 3**: Restart your computer to ensure all changes take effect.

sections.heading: Solution 2: Verify Game Files
sections.content:
Corrupted game files can cause DLL errors. Verifying files will download any missing or damaged files.

**For Steam:**
1. Open Steam Library
2. Right-click **Black Myth Wukong** → **Properties**
3. Go to **Installed Files** tab
4. Click **Verify integrity of game files**
5. Wait for verification to complete (may take 5-30 minutes)
6. Restart Steam and launch the game

**For Epic Games:**
1. Open Epic Games Library
2. Click the **three dots (⋯)** on Black Myth Wukong
3. Select **Manage** → **Verify**
4. Wait for verification

**For GOG Galaxy:**
1. Open GOG Galaxy
2. Select Black Myth Wukong
3. Click **Settings icon** → **Manage Installation** → **Verify / Repair**

**Known Issues:**
- High system requirements (RTX 2060 minimum)

- Ray tracing compatibility problems

sections.heading: Understanding This Error
sections.content:
The **System Error** error is a Windows system error that can disrupt your work or gaming session. This guide provides step-by-step solutions to resolve this issue and prevent it from recurring.

This error typically indicates a system-level problem that can range from corrupted files to hardware issues.

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
This error commonly occurs due to:

1. **Missing or Corrupted System Files**: Essential Windows components are damaged
2. **Registry Issues**: Windows Registry entries are corrupted
3. **Software Conflicts**: Third-party applications interfering with system operations
4. **Insufficient Resources**: Low disk space, memory, or CPU resources
5. **Permission Problems**: Insufficient privileges for required operations
6. **Outdated Components**: Windows or application components need updating

sections.heading: Solution 1: Run Windows Troubleshooter
sections.content:
Windows includes built-in troubleshooters that can automatically detect and fix many issues:

**Step 1**: Open Windows Settings (Win + I)

**Step 2**: Navigate to **System** → **Troubleshoot** → **Other troubleshooters**

**Step 3**: Run relevant troubleshooters:
- **Windows Update** - For update-related errors
- **Program Compatibility** - For application errors
- **Hardware and Devices** - For hardware-related issues
- **Power** - For power-related problems

**Step 4**: Follow the on-screen instructions and apply any suggested fixes

**Step 5**: Restart your computer if prompted

sections.heading: Solution 2: System File Repair
sections.content:
Windows has built-in tools to repair corrupted system files:

**Step 1**: Open Command Prompt as Administrator
- Press **Win + X** → select **Terminal (Admin)**
- Or search "cmd" → right-click → **Run as administrator**

**Step 2**: Run System File Checker
```
sfc /scannow
```
Wait for the scan to complete (10-15 minutes).

**Step 3**: If issues found, run DISM repair
```
DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth
```
This may take 15-30 minutes.

**Step 4**: Restart your computer and try again.

sections.heading: Solution 3: Check Hardware and Drivers
sections.content:
Driver and hardware issues can cause application errors:

**Update Device Drivers:**
1. Press **Win + X** → **Device Manager**
2. Expand each category and look for yellow warning icons
3. Right-click problematic devices → **Update driver**
4. Choose **Search automatically for drivers**

**Update Graphics Driver:**
Visit your GPU manufacturer's website:
- NVIDIA: nvidia.com/drivers
- AMD: amd.com/support
- Intel: intel.com/download-center

**Check Disk Health:**
1. Open Command Prompt as Admin
2. Run: `wmic diskdrive get status`
3. All drives should show "OK"

sections.heading: Preventing Future Errors
sections.content:
Keep your system stable with these practices:

**Regular Maintenance:**
- Run Disk Cleanup monthly to remove temporary files
- Use **sfc /scannow** periodically to check system integrity
- Keep at least 15-20% of your drive space free

**Software Practices:**
- Install software from official sources only
- Uninstall programs you don't use
- Avoid installing multiple antivirus programs

**Updates and Backups:**
- Enable automatic Windows updates
- Create System Restore points before major changes
- Back up important files regularly

**Hardware Care:**
- Keep your PC clean and well-ventilated
- Monitor temperatures during intensive tasks
- Consider replacing old hard drives (5+ years)

faq.question: Can I download kernel32.dll from the internet?
faq.answer: No! kernel32.dll is a protected Windows system file. Downloading DLLs from third-party sites for core Windows components is extremely dangerous and may contain malware. Always use official Windows repair tools like SFC and DISM.

faq.question: Why is kernel32.dll causing problems with Windows 11 startup?
faq.answer: kernel32.dll is part of Windows Core. Windows kernel core library - handles memory, processes, and system calls. When this file is corrupted, missing, or conflicting with other software, it can cause Windows 11 startup to malfunction. This often happens after Windows updates, malware infections, or improper shutdowns.

faq.question: Will reinstalling Windows fix the kernel32.dll error?
faq.answer: Yes, but it's a last resort. Try SFC, DISM, and System Restore first. If those don't work, you can do an in-place upgrade (repair install) which reinstalls Windows while keeping your files and programs. A full reset is rarely needed.

faq.question: Is kernel32.dll error a sign of malware?
faq.answer: It can be. Some malware targets or replaces Windows system files like kernel32.dll. Run a full scan with Windows Defender or another antivirus. If malware is found, clean it first, then repair the system files with SFC/DISM.

sections.heading: Common Causes
sections.content:
This error commonly occurs due to:

1. **Missing or Corrupted System Files**: Essential Windows components are damaged
2. **Registry Issues**: Windows Registry entries are corrupted
3. **Software Conflicts**: Third-party applications interfering with system operations
4. **Insufficient Resources**: Low disk space, memory, or CPU resources
5. **Permission Problems**: Insufficient privileges for required operations
6. **Outdated Components**: Windows or application components need updating

sections.heading: Solution 1: Run Windows Troubleshooter
sections.content:
Windows includes built-in troubleshooters that can automatically detect and fix many issues:

**Step 1**: Open Windows Settings (Win + I)

**Step 2**: Navigate to **System** → **Troubleshoot** → **Other troubleshooters**

**Step 3**: Run relevant troubleshooters:
- **Windows Update** - For update-related errors
- **Program Compatibility** - For application errors
- **Hardware and Devices** - For hardware-related issues
- **Power** - For power-related problems

**Step 4**: Follow the on-screen instructions and apply any suggested fixes

**Step 5**: Restart your computer if prompted

sections.heading: Solution 2: System File Repair
sections.content:
Run these system repair commands as Administrator:

```batch
sfc /scannow
DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth
```

**How to run:** Press Win+X → Terminal (Admin) → paste commands → Enter

Wait for both scans to complete, then restart your PC.

sections.heading: Solution 3: Check Hardware and Drivers
sections.content:
Driver and hardware issues can cause application errors:

**Update Device Drivers:**
1. Press **Win + X** → **Device Manager**
2. Expand each category and look for yellow warning icons
3. Right-click problematic devices → **Update driver**
4. Choose **Search automatically for drivers**

**Update Graphics Driver:**
Visit your GPU manufacturer's website:
- NVIDIA: nvidia.com/drivers
- AMD: amd.com/support
- Intel: intel.com/download-center

**Check Disk Health:**
1. Open Command Prompt as Admin
2. Run: `wmic diskdrive get status`
3. All drives should show "OK"

sections.heading: Preventing Future Errors
sections.content:
Keep your system stable with these practices:

**Regular Maintenance:**
- Run Disk Cleanup monthly to remove temporary files
- Use **sfc /scannow** periodically to check system integrity
- Keep at least 15-20% of your drive space free

**Software Practices:**
- Install software from official sources only
- Uninstall programs you don't use
- Avoid installing multiple antivirus programs

**Updates and Backups:**
- Enable automatic Windows updates
- Create System Restore points before major changes
- Back up important files regularly

**Hardware Care:**
- Keep your PC clean and well-ventilated
- Monitor temperatures during intensive tasks
- Consider replacing old hard drives (5+ years)

faq.question: Can I download user32.dll from the internet?
faq.answer: No! user32.dll is a protected Windows system file. Downloading DLLs from third-party sites for core Windows components is extremely dangerous and may contain malware. Always use official Windows repair tools like SFC and DISM.

faq.question: Why is user32.dll causing problems with Windows 11 startup?
faq.answer: user32.dll is part of Windows Core. Windows User Interface library. When this file is corrupted, missing, or conflicting with other software, it can cause Windows 11 startup to malfunction. This often happens after Windows updates, malware infections, or improper shutdowns.

faq.question: Will reinstalling Windows fix the user32.dll error?
faq.answer: Yes, but it's a last resort. Try SFC, DISM, and System Restore first. If those don't work, you can do an in-place upgrade (repair install) which reinstalls Windows while keeping your files and programs. A full reset is rarely needed.

faq.question: Is user32.dll error a sign of malware?
faq.answer: It can be. Some malware targets or replaces Windows system files like user32.dll. Run a full scan with Windows Defender or another antivirus. If malware is found, clean it first, then repair the system files with SFC/DISM.

sections.heading: Common Causes

This error commonly occurs due to:

1. **Missing or Corrupted System Files**: Essential Windows components are damaged
2. **Registry Issues**: Windows Registry entries are corrupted
3. **Software Conflicts**: Third-party applications interfering with system operations
4. **Insufficient Resources**: Low disk space, memory, or CPU resources

sections.heading: Solution 1: Run Windows Troubleshooter
sections.content:

- **Program Compatibility** - For application errors
- **Hardware and Devices** - For hardware-related issues

sections.heading: Solution 2: System File Repair
sections.content:

**Run these commands in order:**

1. **Check system file integrity:**
```
sfc /scannow
```

2. **Repair Windows image (if SFC found issues):**
```
DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth
```

3. **Re-run SFC after DISM:**
```
sfc /scannow
```

Restart your computer after these repairs complete.

sections.heading: Solution 3: Check Hardware and Drivers
sections.content:
Driver and hardware issues can cause application errors:

**Update Device Drivers:**
1. Press **Win + X** → **Device Manager**
2. Expand each category and look for yellow warning icons
3. Right-click problematic devices → **Update driver**
4. Choose **Search automatically for drivers**

**Update Graphics Driver:**
Visit your GPU manufacturer's website:
- NVIDIA: nvidia.com/drivers
- AMD: amd.com/support
- Intel: intel.com/download-center

**Check Disk Health:**
1. Open Command Prompt as Admin
2. Run: `wmic diskdrive get status`
3. All drives should show "OK"

sections.heading: Preventing Future Errors
sections.content:
Keep your system stable with these practices:

**Regular Maintenance:**
- Run Disk Cleanup monthly to remove temporary files
- Use **sfc /scannow** periodically to check system integrity

**Software Practices:**
- Install software from official sources only
- Uninstall programs you don't use
- Avoid installing multiple antivirus programs

**Updates and Backups:**
- Enable automatic Windows updates
- Create System Restore points before major changes
- Back up important files regularly

**Hardware Care:**
- Keep your PC clean and well-ventilated
- Monitor temperatures during intensive tasks

Windows includes built-in troubleshooters that can automatically detect and fix many issues:

**Step 1**: Open Windows Settings (Win + I)

**Step 2**: Navigate to **System** → **Troubleshoot** → **Other troubleshooters**

**Step 3**: Run relevant troubleshooters:
- **Windows Update** - For update-related errors
- **Program Compatibility** - For application errors
- **Hardware and Devices** - For hardware-related issues
- **Power** - For power-related problems

**Step 4**: Follow the on-screen instructions and apply any suggested fixes

**Step 5**: Restart your computer if prompted

sections.heading: Solution 2: System File Repair
sections.content:
Windows has built-in tools to repair corrupted system files:

**Step 1**: Open Command Prompt as Administrator
- Press **Win + X** → select **Terminal (Admin)**
- Or search "cmd" → right-click → **Run as administrator**

**Step 2**: Run System File Checker
```
sfc /scannow
```
Wait for the scan to complete (10-15 minutes).

**Step 3**: If issues found, run DISM repair
```
DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth
```
This may take 15-30 minutes.

**Step 4**: Restart your computer and try again.

sections.heading: Solution 3: Check Hardware and Drivers
sections.content:
Driver and hardware issues can cause application errors:

**Update Device Drivers:**
1. Press **Win + X** → **Device Manager**
2. Expand each category and look for yellow warning icons
3. Right-click problematic devices → **Update driver**
4. Choose **Search automatically for drivers**

**Update Graphics Driver:**
Visit your GPU manufacturer's website:
- NVIDIA: nvidia.com/drivers
- AMD: amd.com/support
- Intel: intel.com/download-center

**Check Disk Health:**
1. Open Command Prompt as Admin
2. Run: `wmic diskdrive get status`
3. All drives should show "OK"

sections.heading: Preventing Future Errors
sections.content:
Keep your system stable with these practices:

**Regular Maintenance:**
- Run Disk Cleanup monthly to remove temporary files
- Use **sfc /scannow** periodically to check system integrity
- Keep at least 15-20% of your drive space free

**Software Practices:**
- Install software from official sources only
- Uninstall programs you don't use
- Avoid installing multiple antivirus programs

**Updates and Backups:**
- Enable automatic Windows updates
- Create System Restore points before major changes
- Back up important files regularly

**Hardware Care:**
- Keep your PC clean and well-ventilated
- Monitor temperatures during intensive tasks
- Consider replacing old hard drives (5+ years)
